item.title: World Bank Lifts Ban on Nuclear Power, Considers Upstream Gas
item.description: The World Bank’s board lifted its ban on supporting nuclear power, and is discussing whether to fund natural exploration and production, as it seeks ways to bolster access to electricity to realize its core development goals.
item.dc:creator: Ramsey Al-Rikabi

media:content.media:description: Ajay Banga

item.title: Group of Seven Tries to Avoid Trump Conflict by Scrapping Joint Communique
item.description: Group of Seven nations won’t try to reach consensus on a joint communique at next week’s leaders summit in Canada, people familiar with the matter said, an acknowledgment of the wide gulf that separates the US from the other members on Ukraine, climate change and other issues.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Jorge Valero, Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump and Mark Carney, Canada’s prime minister, during a meeting in the Oval Office on May 6.

item.title: RFK Jr.’s New Vaccine Panel Includes Self-Proclaimed Anti-Vaxxer
item.description: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. announced eight new members of an expert panel that advises the federal government on immunization policy, a group that includes several vocal vaccine critics and one who identifies as an “anti-vaxxer.”
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang, Gerry Smith

media:content.media:description: HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

item.title: US to Pull Some Embassy Staff From Middle East as Tensions Rise
item.description: The US ordered some staff to depart the embassy in Baghdad and allowed military service members’ families to leave the Middle East, officials said, after Iran threatened to attack US bases if talks over its nuclear program fall through.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay, Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: The US Embassy in Baghdad, Iraq.

item.title: Colombia’s Petro Moves Ahead With Labor Referendum Despite Rising Violence
item.description: President Gustavo Petro signed a decree for a labor-rights referendum as Colombia grapples with a surge in armed attacks.
item.dc:creator: Andreina Itriago

media:content.media:description: Members of trade unions, student organizations, social groups, and community organizations participate in a march in support of the referendum and social reforms proposed by the government of Colombia's President Gustavo Petro in Bogota on June 11, 2025.

item.title: Ex-Columbia Student Khalil Ordered Released From ICE Custody
item.description: A former Columbia University graduate who has been fighting deportation over his participation in pro-Palestinian protests was ordered released from an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility by a federal judge.
item.dc:creator: Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil is seen at a pro-Palestinian protest encampment on the Columbia University campus in New York, April 29, 2024. (AP Photo/Ted Shaffrey, File)

item.title: Cruz Pitches $1.1 Trillion Cut to Fed Bank Payments for Trump Tax Bill
item.description: Texas Senator Ted Cruz pitched Republican senators Wednesday on ending the Federal Reserve’s authority to pay interest to banks, claiming it would save $1.1 trillion over a decade, with members of the party’s conservative flank lauding the idea.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Alex Harris

media:content.media:description: Republican Senator Ted Cruz.

item.title: Pentagon Mulls Scrapping Aukus Agreement With Australia and UK
item.description: The Pentagon has launched a review of the Biden-era Aukus pact to develop nuclear-powered submarines with Australia and the UK, as the Trump administration looks to shift the burden for collective defense to allies and make sure the US has enough warships of its own.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: The Virgina-class USS Idaho was christened in a ceremony on March 16.

item.title: Social Media Firms Accountable for Posts, Brazil Judges Conclude
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court formed a majority in favor of further regulating social media companies, the latest effort by authorities to hold tech giants accountable for illegal content posted on their platforms.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Rosati, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes

item.title: Republican Senators Consider $30,000 SALT Cap in Trump Tax Bill
item.description: Republican senators are considering placing a $30,000 cap on the state and local tax deduction as a compromise between current law and the more generous limit in the House’s version of President Donald Trump’s tax bill, a key GOP negotiator said.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The Senate side of the US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: LA Protests Pit Gavin Newsom as Antagonist Against Donald Trump
item.description: After months of courting Republicans, the Democratic governor now warns Trump is undermining democracy with the military deployment in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher, John Gittelsohn

media:content.media:description: Governor Gavin Newsom speaks during a televised address on June 10. Source: Office of California Governor/Office of California Governor

item.title: Senate GOP Seeks to Scale Back Food Aid Cuts in Trump Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans plan to scale back cuts to federal food aid for the poor that their counterparts in the House used to help pay for Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending package, a key senator said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator John Boozman,

item.title: US Tariff Revenue Hits Fresh Record, Helping Shrink May Deficit
item.description: US customs duties climbed to a record in May, helping shrink the budget deficit for the month, while doubts remain about the persistence of the inflows as the Trump administration negotiates with trading partners and faces a judicial challenge over its levies.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: A container ship at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles, California, US, on Friday, April 4, 2025. President Donald Trump blasted China for retaliating against his sweeping tariff plan and vowed his economic policies will never change, as the prospect of a trade war wreaked more havoc on the global economy.

item.title: Pentagon Slashes in Half Its Request for Air Force F-35s
item.description: The Air Force has cut in half its request to Congress for its signature F-35s, dealing a blow to Lockheed Martin Corp., the top US defense contractor.
item.dc:creator: Roxana Tiron, Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: A US Air Force F35A fighter jet. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Fulbright Board Quits, Says Trump Aides Blocked Scholarships
item.description: The Fulbright Foreign Scholarship Board resigned en masse to protest what it called unprecedented interference after the Trump administration denied a significant number of US academics from receiving the prestigious awards.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Case

media:content.media:description: The US State Department headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: Why China Can Afford to Wait for a Deal, and the US Can’t
item.description: On this episode of Trumponomics, we discuss the status of Washington’s trade war negotiations with Beijing, and why Xi Jinping still has the upper hand.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: He Lifeng, China's vice premier, departs following trade talks at Lancaster House in London, UK, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025. The US and China resumed talks into a second day, with financial markets on edge as the world's largest economies try to agree to allow exports of key tech and industrial goods and avoid escalating their trade war.

item.title: As Protests Spread, Both Parties Gird for Confrontation
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior editor Joe Sobczyk looks at the politics of the immigration protests. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Joe Sobczyk

item.title: What to Know About the Legal Battle Over Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The fate of President Donald Trump’s trade war lies in the hands of the courts as a legal battle plays out over his use of emergency powers to impose tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Josh Wingrove, Shawn Donnan, Laura Curtis

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump holds a poster detailing the reciprocal tariffs during an announcement in the White House Rose Garden in Washington, DC, on April 2, 2025. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Global Fertility Crisis Can't Be Solved With Financial Perks, UN Report Says
item.description: Solving the global fertility crisis would require creating conditions that support parenting instead of pushing economic incentives, according to a new UN report.
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Del Valle

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians with children walk through Dilworth Park in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, U.S., on Saturday, July 31, 2021. Philadelphia, as well as Montgomery and Delaware counties, are seeing "substantial" levels of COVID-19 transmission, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

item.title: Trump’s Repeal of Pollution Rules Paves Way for New Dirty Plants
item.description: The Trump administration’s plan to repeal power-plant pollution mandates will make it easier and cheaper for utilities to build new fossil fuel-fired plants, while stalling investment in clean energy.
item.dc:creator: Mark Chediak

media:content.media:description: The Gateway Generating Station natural gas-fired power plant in Antioch, California, US, on Thursday, Feb. 9, 2023. California Governor Gavin Newsom called for federal energy regulators to investigate a recent hike in natural gas prices that has resulted in sky-high utility bills.

item.title: Bally’s Casino Gets NYC Council Boost After Push from Mayor
item.description: The New York City Council recommended that the state legislature allow Bally’s Corp. to use public park land for a casino in the Bronx after a last minute push from Mayor Eric Adams.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan, Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Eric Adams, mayor of New York, speaks during the Crypto Summit in New York, US, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. The event gathers founders, CEOs, and investors from the cryptocurrency, blockchain and fintech industries to discuss how the industry can boost the economy, attract top talent, and inspire innovation in New York City.

item.title: Downtown LA Set for Second Night of Curfew as Trump Crackdown Expands
item.description: Protests over immigration raids that began in Los Angeles continued to spread across the US as President Donald Trump escalated his crackdown by unleashing new federal powers.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher, Isabela Fleischmann, Maxwell Adler

media:content.media:description: An LAPD officer shouting at a demonstrator during a protest against the immigration raids in Los Angeles on June 10, 2025.

item.title: US Tariffs Threaten to Derail Vietnam’s Historic Industrial Boom
item.description: An economic boom lifted the country of 100 million out of poverty. Then came the Trump rug-pull.
item.dc:creator: Anders Melin, Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen, Francesca Stevens

media:content.media:description: Shopkeeper Dinh Ngoc Hien outside her store in Dong Nai province, near Ho Chi Minh City.

item.title: Canada Eyes Further Moves to Counter Foreign Steel Dumping
item.description: Canadian Industry Minister Melanie Joly said the government will soon announce measures to clamp down on steel dumping from foreign countries and help domestic manufacturers hit by punishing US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: Spools of steel in Hamilton, Ontario.

item.title: US Urges Court Not to Limit Trump’s Use of Troops in LA
item.description: The US Justice Department urged a federal judge not to interfere with the Trump administration’s deployment of the National Guard and US Marines to respond to deportation protests in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris, Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: Members of the California National Guard stand guard outside the Federal Building before a curfew takes effect in Los Angeles on June 10, 2025.

item.title: Trump Says China Will Ship Rare Earths in ‘Done’ Trade Deal
item.description: President Donald Trump said a trade framework with China has been completed, with Beijing supplying rare earths and magnets “UP FRONT” and the US allowing Chinese students into its colleges and universities.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Skylar Woodhouse

item.title: Crypto Industry-Backed Stablecoin Bill Advances in US Senate
item.description: The Senate advanced bipartisan stablecoin legislation supported by the crypto industry and President Donald Trump, with final passage of the measure likely next week.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Visitors take photos outside the US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: Musk Voiced Regret Over Trump Feud After Talk With Allies
item.description: Elon Musk issued his strongest sign of contrition yet over his handling of the dramatic break with Donald Trump, days after a call with two of the president’s top allies.
item.dc:creator: William Selway, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: Trump and Musk at the White House in March.

item.title: US Makes Export Controls Negotiable as Part of China Trade Talks
item.description: Trade talks between the US and China this week cemented a seismic change in Washington’s approach to the countries’ economic relationship: US export curbs, meant to keep sensitive technologies out of Beijing’s hands, are now explicitly up for negotiation.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Mackenzie Hawkins

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, second right, departs following trade talks at Lancaster House in London, UK, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025.

item.title: Labour Gambles on Growth Boost Outside London to Beat Farage
item.description: Rachel Reeves will pump billions of pounds into areas outside London as the Labour government tries to head off an electoral threat posed by Nigel Farage’s Reform UK.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Alex Wickham, Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves
